message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Adaptive Fault-Tolerant Tracking Control for Discrete-Time Multiagent Systems via Reinforcement Learning Algorithm
Paper Abstract: This article investigates the adaptive fault-tolerant tracking control problem for a class of discrete-time multiagent systems via a reinforcement learning algorithm. The action neural networks (NNs) are used to approximate unknown and desired control input signals, and the critic NNs are employed to estimate the cost function in the design procedure. Furthermore, the direct adaptive optimal controllers are designed by combining the backstepping technique with the reinforcement learning algorithm. Comparing the existing reinforcement learning algorithm, the computational burden can be effectively reduced by using the method of less learning parameters. The adaptive auxiliary signals are established to compensate for the influence of the dead zones and actuator faults on the control performance. Based on the Lyapunov stability theory, it is proved that all signals of the closed-loop system are semiglobally uniformly ultimately bounded. Finally, some simulation results are presented to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Fault tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_tolerance"},{"title":"System Fault Tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_Fault_Tolerance"},{"title":"Software fault tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_fault_tolerance"},{"title":"Category:Fault-tolerant computer systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Fault-tolerant_computer_systems"},{"title":"Byzantine fault - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byzantine_fault"},{"title":"State machine replication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_machine_replication"},{"title":"Fault Tolerant Ethernet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_Tolerant_Ethernet"},{"title":"Intrusion tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intrusion_tolerance"},{"title":"Stratus Technologies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stratus_Technologies"},{"title":"Quantum Byzantine agreement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_Byzantine_agreement"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about fault-tolerant systems:

## Definition

Fault tolerance is the ability of a system to maintain proper operation despite failures or faults in one or more of its components.(no content)This capability is essential for high-availability, mission-critical, or even life-critical systems.

## Key Characteristics

Fault tolerance specifically refers to a system's capability to handle faults without any degradation or downtime.(no content)In the event of an error, end-users remain unaware of any issues.

## Approaches and Methods

Several methods are used to implement fault tolerance:

- **Redundancy**: N-model redundancy, where faults cause automatic fail-safes and a warning to the operator, is the most common form of level one fault-tolerant design in use today.

- **Hardware-Based**: Hardware fault tolerance sometimes requires that broken parts be removed and replaced with new parts while the system is still operational (in computing known as hot swapping).

- **Software-Based**: Software fault tolerance is the ability of computer software to continue its normal operation despite the presence of system or hardware faults.

## Real-World Applications

Tandem Computers built their entire business on such machines, which used single-point tolerance to create their NonStop systems with uptimes measured in years.

Links: [{"title":"Fault tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_tolerance"},{"title":"System Fault Tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_Fault_Tolerance"},{"title":"Software fault tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_fault_tolerance"},{"title":"Category:Fault-tolerant computer systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Fault-tolerant_computer_systems"},{"title":"Byzantine fault - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byzantine_fault"},{"title":"State machine replication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_machine_replication"},{"title":"Fault Tolerant Ethernet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fault_Tolerant_Ethernet"},{"title":"Intrusion tolerance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intrusion_tolerance"},{"title":"Stratus Technologies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stratus_Technologies"},{"title":"Quantum Byzantine agreement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_Byzantine_agreement"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about fault-tolerant systems:

## Definition

Fault tolerance is the ability of a system to maintain proper operation despite failures or faults in one or more of its components.(no content)This capability is essential for high-availability, mission-critical, or even life-critical systems.

## Key Characteristics

Fault tolerance specifically refers to a system's capability to handle faults without any degradation or downtime.(no content)In the event of an error, end-users remain unaware of any issues.

## Approaches and Methods

Several methods are used to implement fault tolerance:

- **Redundancy**: N-model redundancy, where faults cause automatic fail-safes and a warning to the operator, is the most common form of level one fault-tolerant design in use today.

- **Hardware-Based**: Hardware fault tolerance sometimes requires that broken parts be removed and replaced with new parts while the system is still operational (in computing known as hot swapping).

- **Software-Based**: Software fault tolerance is the ability of computer software to continue its normal operation despite the presence of system or hardware faults.

## Real-World Applications

Tandem Computers built their entire business on such machines, which used single-point tolerance to create their NonStop systems with uptimes measured in years.

Based on the search results, here's what a multi-agent system is:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have important characteristics including autonomy (agents are at least partially independent and self-aware) and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).

## Modern Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Composition and Agents

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment, typically referring to software agents, though the agents could equally well be robots, humans, or human teams.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance, and social structure modelling.

Multi-agent systems represent an important area of artificial intelligence research that leverages the collaborative power of multiple autonomous entities to tackle complex problems.

Web search results for query: "Adaptive control"

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Adaptive cruise control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_cruise_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Self-tuning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-tuning"},{"title":"Adaptive traffic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_traffic_control"},{"title":"Continuous monitoring and adaptive control (stormwater management) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_monitoring_and_adaptive_control_(stormwater_management)"},{"title":"Xbox Adaptive Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Adaptive_Controller#:~:text=The co-creator of the,much they could be ..."},{"title":"Real-time adaptive security - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_adaptive_security"},{"title":"File:Xbox Adaptive Controller V&A.JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Xbox_Adaptive_Controller_V&A.JPG"},{"title":"Adaptive autonomy","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_autonomy"}]

## Adaptive Control - Search Results

Here are the results from the web search for "Adaptive control":

**Core Definition:**
Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

**Key Difference from Robust Control:**
Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

**Foundation and Methods:**
The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

**Types of Adaptive Control:**
Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters. Hybrid methods rely on both estimation of parameters and direct modification of the control law.

**Modern Applications:**
In recent times, adaptive control has been merged with intelligent techniques such as fuzzy and neural networks to bring forth new concepts such as fuzzy adaptive control.(no content)A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control.

Links: [{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Self-play (reinforcement learning technique) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-play_(reinforcement_learning_technique)"},{"title":"Model-free (reinforcement learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-free_(reinforcement_learning)"},{"title":"Category:Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"Self-supervised learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-supervised_learning"},{"title":"Imitation learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imitation_learning"}]

Here's what I found about reinforcement learning:

## Overview

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## Key Characteristics

Unlike supervised and unsupervised learning which work with labeled and unlabeled data respectively, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

## Applications

Reinforcement learning has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.(no content)Deep reinforcement learning has been used for a diverse set of applications including robotics, video games, natural language processing, computer vision, education, transportation, finance and healthcare.

## Subfields and Variants

The search results reveal several important subfields and variants of reinforcement learning, including:
- Deep reinforcement learning (deep RL) is a subfield of machine learning that combines reinforcement learning and deep learning.
- Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.
- Reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) is a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences.

Kokotovic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petar_V._Kokotovic"},{"title":"Talk:Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Backstepping"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Backpropagation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation"},{"title":"Back mount - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Back_mount"},{"title":"Backstay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstay"},{"title":"Exponential backoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_backoff"}]

Here are the search results for **Backstepping control**:

## Overview

Backstepping provides a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)Backstepping is a technique that takes advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory for controlling nonlinear systems.

## How It Works

The single-step procedure can be completed iteratively to stabilize an entire strict-feedback system. In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-integrator strict-feedback system is isolated. Feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system. The resulting single-integrator system is stabilized. The stabilized system is used as the upper system in the next step.

## Application and Significance

Systems instrict-feedback form can be stabilized by recursive application of backstepping.(no content)Petar V. Kokotovic made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control especially the backstepping stabilization method.

Backstepping is particularly useful for handling complex nonlinear systems in fields like robotics and aerospace, where linear control techniques may be insufficient.

Here's a comprehensive overview of neural networks based on the search results:

## What is a Neural Network?

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)In machine learning, a neural network is an artificial mathematical model used to approximate nonlinear functions.

## Structure

Neurons in an artificial neural network are usually arranged into layers, with information passing from the first layer (the input layer) through one or more intermediate layers (the hidden layers) to the final layer (the output layer).(no content)The behavior of the network depends on the strengths (or weights) of the connections between neurons. A network is trained by modifying these weights through empirical risk minimization or backpropagation in order to fit some preexisting dataset.

## Applications

Neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

## Learning

Neural networks can learn from experience, and can derive conclusions from a complex and seemingly unrelated set of information. Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference, or empirical risk, between the predicted output and the actual target values in a given dataset.

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Lyapunov stability:

## Overview

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.

## Definition and Concept

Near to a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable the system remains stable under small disturbances. More specifically, Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium remain close enough, while asymptotic stability means solutions that start close enough not only remain close but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

## Historical Significance

A. M. Lyapunov was a pioneer in successful endeavors to develop a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.(no content)More recently the concept of the Lyapunov exponent (related to Lyapunov's First Method of discussing stability) has received wide interest in connection with chaos theory.

## Lyapunov Functions

Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Applications

The main two approaches to analysis for systems with inputs are BIBO stability (for linear systems) and input-to-state stability (ISS) (for nonlinear systems).

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Lyapunov stability:

## Overview

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.

## Definition and Concept

Near to a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable the system remains stable under small disturbances. More specifically, Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium remain close enough, while asymptotic stability means solutions that start close enough not only remain close but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

## Historical Significance

A. M. Lyapunov was a pioneer in successful endeavors to develop a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.(no content)More recently the concept of the Lyapunov exponent (related to Lyapunov's First Method of discussing stability) has received wide interest in connection with chaos theory.

## Lyapunov Functions

Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Applications

The main two approaches to analysis for systems with inputs are BIBO stability (for linear systems) and input-to-state stability (ISS) (for nonlinear systems).

message_text:
## Summary

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Adaptive Fault-Tolerant Tracking Control for Discrete-Time Multiagent Systems via Reinforcement Learning Algorithm" and extracted all key technologies and methodologies. Here's what was completed:

**Paper Classification:** ✅ Contribution  
The paper proposes novel methods for adaptive fault-tolerant tracking control, combining reinforcement learning with backstepping techniques.

**Key Entities Identified (7 triples):**

1. **Reinforcement learning** (method, uses) - Core algorithm for designing the adaptive controller
2. **Artificial neural network** (method, uses) - Action and critic NNs for function approximation
3. **Backstepping** (method, uses) - Stabilization technique combined with RL
4. **Adaptive control** (method, proposes) - Novel adaptive approach for fault tolerance
5. **Lyapunov stability** (concept, uses) - Theoretical framework for stability proof
6. **Fault tolerance** (concept, proposes) - Novel fault-tolerant tracking control method
7. **Multi-agent system** (task, uses) - Application domain for the control method

**Validation:** ✅ All checks passed  
- Paper type correctly set as "contribution"
- All triples properly documented with Wikipedia URLs
- Meets validation requirements (≥1 "uses" and ≥1 "proposes" for contribution papers)

The triples_output.json file has been successfully updated and validated.
